==References== {{reflist|25em}}
[[Category:Medicare and Medicaid (United States)]] [[Category:Healthcare in the United States]] [[Category:Health economics]]

A '''health crisis''' or '''public health crisis''' is a difficult situation or complex [[health system]] that affects humans in one or more geographic areas (mainly occurred in natural hazards), from a particular locality to encompass the entire planet. Health crises generally have significant impacts on community health, loss of life, and on the economy. They may result from disease, industrial processes or poor policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Decade/top-10-health-scares-past-10-years/comments?type=story&id=9249373#.T9ZQZbDUPbi|title=Joseph Brownstein. The Top 10 Health Scares Of The Decade. ABC News. 07/12/2009.|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equipocesca.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/gripe-a-crisis-sespas-2010-jg-rm.pdf|title=Gérvas J, Meneu R. Public health crises in a developed society. Successes and limitations in Spain. SESPAS report 2010. Gac Sanit. 2010; 24(Supl 1):33-6.|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923203449/http://www.equipocesca.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/gripe-a-crisis-sespas-2010-jg-rm.pdf|archivedate=2011-09-23|df=}}</ref>
Its severity is often measured by the number of people affected by its geographical extent, or the [[disease]] or death of the pathogenic process which it originates.<ref>Alderson MR. Mortality, morbidity, and health statistics. New York: Stockton Press; 1988. {{ISBN|0-935859-31-4}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v474/n7350_supp/pdf/474S2a.pdf Gravitz L. A smouldering public-health crisis. Nature. 2011/06/09; 474:S2-4. ] {{doi|10.1038/474S2a}}</ref>
== Features == [[File:AcampamentoHaiti2.jpg|thumb| Having lost their homes in the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|earthquake]], many Haitians now live in precarious camps.]] Generally there are three key components in health crises:<ref>Noji EK. The public health consequences of disasters. Oxford: OUP; 1997.</ref> * Public health problem<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2011/07/30/indias-public-health-crisis-the-government-responds/|title=India’s Public Health Crisis: The Government Responds|first=Geeta|last=Anand|date=30 July 2011|publisher=}}</ref> * Problem health coordination * Alarm care: Poor communication of risks to the population resulting in social upheaval.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.publico.es/joan-carles-march-cerda/tag/crisis/|title=crisis|first=|last=Público|publisher=}}</ref>
== Types == * Environmental * Food * Infectious * Toxic

== Prevention and control == * Using the '''health warning systems'''. A health system responsive to the needs of the population is required to refine the instruments to ensure adequate preparation before their hatching.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.cdc.gov/HAN/|title=Health Alert Network (HAN). Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Atlanta. 2011/08/29.|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110912180424/http://www.bt.cdc.gov/HAN/|archivedate=2011-09-12|df=}}</ref><ref>Valencia R, Román E, García-León FJ, et al. Sistemas de alerta: una prioridad de la vigilancia epidemiológica. Gac Sanit. 2003;17:520–2.</ref><ref>Fernández K, Ciotti M, Kaiser R. La Unión Europea ante las crisis sanitarias. Rev Adm Sanit. 2006; 4:425–35.</ref> * '''Transparency of the institutions''' public or private. The perception of crisis can escape the control of experts or health institutions, and be determined by stakeholders to provide solutions propagate or concerned. This requires a difficult balancing of the need to articulate clear answers and the little-founded fears.<ref>Abouzhr C, Adjei S, Kanchanachitra C. From data to policy: good practices and cautionary tales. Lancet. 2007; 369:1039–46.</ref> * Adequate '''information policy'''. Irrationality arise when information is distorted, or hidden. Face a health crisis involves: respect for society, coordination of organizations and an institution with scientific weight to the people and to the media, who acted as spokesman in situations of public health risk, to get confidence citizens. The technical capacity of health professionals is more proven than the public officials, which suggests a greater share of the former and better training of the second.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthcommunication/Risks/|title=Risk Communication- Gateway to Health Communication - CDC|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcs.es/publicaciones/sistema_sanitario_situaciones_crisis.html|title=El Sistema Sanitario ante situaciones de crisis|first=Quodem Consultores S.L.|last=www.quodem.com|publisher=}}</ref><ref>Lamata F. Crisis sanitaria y respuesta política. Rev Adm Sanit. 2006; 4:401–6.</ref> * '''Evaluate the previous crisis''' or others experiences. Crises are challenges that must be learned from both the mistakes and successes, since they serve to bring about to the devices and improve the response to other crises. It is important to perform analysis of previous responses, audit risk and vulnerability, research and testing, and drills to prepare themselves against future crises.<ref>Spiegel PB, Le P, Ververs MT, et al. Occurrence and overlap of natural disasters, complex emergencies and epidemics during the past decade(1995–2004). Conflict Health. 2007; 1:2.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-06-18-texas-health-care_N.htm|title=What does a health crisis look like? See Houston - USATODAY.com|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equipocesca.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/crisis-2009-aciertos-y-errores.pdf|title=Gérvas J, Hernández-Aguado I, et al. Successes and failures in the management of public health crisis in Spain. Gac Sanit. 2009;23(1):67–71|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923190452/http://www.equipocesca.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/crisis-2009-aciertos-y-errores.pdf|archivedate=2011-09-23|df=}}</ref> * Having '''objectives''': "first, to reduce the impact of illness and death, and second, to avoid social fracture".<ref>Weinstein RA. Planning for epidemics--the lessons of SARS. N Engl J Med. 2004; 350(23):2332-4.</ref> * Preparing '''contingency plans'''. Preparation is key to the crisis because it allows a strong response, organized, and scientifically based. Action plans must meet the professional early enough and properly trained, and politicians must be consistent in their actions and coordinate all available resources. It is essential to invest in public health resources to prepare preventive measures and reducing health inequalities to minimize the impact of health crises, as they generally always the poorest suffer most.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2006/mar/23/the-health-care-crisis-and-what-to-do-about-it/|title=The Health Care Crisis and What to Do About It|first=Paul Krugman and Robin|last=Wells|date=23 March 2006|publisher=|via=The New York Review of Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equipocesca.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/crisis-2007-05-22-el-pais-el-eterno-retorno-de-las-crisis-sanitarias.pdf|title=Gérvas J, Hernández I. El eterno retorno de las crisis sanitarias. El País. 22/05/2007.|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317165214/http://www.equipocesca.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/crisis-2007-05-22-el-pais-el-eterno-retorno-de-las-crisis-sanitarias.pdf|archivedate=2012-03-17|df=}}</ref>

The New York Times. 2010/10/21.] * [http://www.social-europe.eu/2012/11/spain-is-experiencing-a-period-of-intense-social-crisis/ Navarro V. Spain is experiencing a Period of intense Social Crisis. revision.comment: adding links to references using [[Google Scholar]]
revision.text:
'''Health equity''' refers to the study and causes of differences in the quality of [[health]] and [[healthcare]] across different populations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glossary of a Few Key Public Health Terms|url=http://www.cdphe.state.co.us/ohd/glossary.html|publisher=Office of Health Disparities, Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Health equity is different from health equality, as it refers only to the absence of disparities in controllable or remediable aspects of health. It is not possible to work towards complete equality in health, as there are some factors of health that are beyond human influence.<ref>WHO | Equity. (n.d.). ''WHO''. Retrieved February 27, 2014, from http://www.who.int/healthsystems/topics/equity/en/</ref> Inequity implies some kind of social injustice. Thus, if one population dies younger than another because of genetic differences, a non-remediable/controllable factor, we tend to say that there is a health inequality. On the other hand, if a population has a lower life expectancy due to lack of access to medications, the situation would be classified as a health inequity.<ref>Kawachi I., Subramanian S., Almeida-Filho N. "A glossary for health inequalities. ''J Epidemiol Community Health'' 2002;56:647–652;56:647–652</ref> These inequities may include differences in the "presence of disease, health outcomes, or access to health care"<ref name=goldberg-ohio>Goldberg, J., Hayes, W., and Huntley, J. "Understanding Health Disparities." Health Policy Institute of Ohio (November 2004), page 3.</ref> between populations with a different [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[ethnic groups|ethnicity]], [[sexual orientation]] or [[socioeconomic]] status.<ref>U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), [[Healthy People 2010]]: National Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Objectives, conference ed. in two vols (Washington, D.C., January 2000).</ref>
Health equity falls into two major categories: horizontal equity, the equal treatment of individuals or groups in the same circumstances; and vertical equity, the principle that individuals who are unequal should be treated differently according to their level of need.<ref>JAN. Economic Analysis For Management And Policy [e-book]. Open University Press; 2005 [cited 2013 Mar 21]. Available from: MyiLibrary. <http://lib.myilibrary.com?ID=95419></ref> Disparities in the quality of health across populations are well-documented globally in both developed and developing nations. The importance of equitable access to healthcare has been cited as crucial to achieving many of the [[Millennium Development Goals]].<ref>Vandemoortele, Milo (2010) [http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=4751&title=millennium-development-goals-equity-development The MDGs and equity] Overseas Development Institute</ref>
== Socioeconomic status == [[Socioeconomic status]] is both a strong predictor of health, and a key factor underlying health inequities across populations<ref>Simandan, D., 2018. Rethinking the health consequences of social class and social mobility. Social Science & Medicine. Vol. 200, pp. 258-261. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.11.037 .</ref>. Poor socioeconomic status has the capacity to profoundly limit the [[Capability approach#Capabilities|capabilities]] of an individual or population, manifesting itself through deficiencies in both [[Financial capital|financial]] and [[social capital]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Ben-Shlomo Yoav, White Ian R., Marmot Michael | year = 1996 | title = Does the Variation in the Socioeconomic Characteristics of an Area Affect Mortality? | url = | journal = BMJ | volume = 312 | issue = 7037| pages = 1013–1014 | doi=10.1136/bmj.312.7037.1013| pmc = 2350820 }}</ref> It is clear how a lack of financial capital can compromise the capacity to maintain good health. In the UK, prior to the institution of the [[National Health Service|NHS]] reforms in the early 2000s, it was shown that income was an important determinant of access to healthcare resources.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Morris S. |author2=Sutton M. |author3=Gravelle H. | year = 2005 | title = Inequity and inequality in the use of health care in England: an empirical investigation | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 60 | issue = 6| pages = 1251–1266 | doi = 10.1016/j.socscimed.2004.07.016 |pmid=15626522 }}</ref> Because one's job or career is a primary conduit for both financial and social capital, work is an important, yet under represented, factor in health inequities research and prevention efforts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ahonen|first=Emily Quinn|last2=Fujishiro|first2=Kaori|last3=Cunningham|first3=Thomas|last4=Flynn|first4=Michael|date=2018-01-18|title=Work as an Inclusive Part of Population Health Inequities Research and Prevention|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=108|issue=3|pages=306–311|doi=10.2105/ajph.2017.304214|pmid=29345994|pmc=5803801|issn=0090-0036}}</ref> Maintenance of good health through the utilization of proper healthcare resources can be quite costly and therefore unaffordable to certain populations.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | author = Kawachi I., Kennedy B. P. | year = 1997 | title = Health and Social Cohesion: Why Care about Income Inequality? | journal = BMJ | volume = 314 | issue = 7086| pages = 1037–1040 | doi=10.1136/bmj.314.7086.1037 | pmid=9112854 | pmc=2126438}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Shi L ''et al.'' | year = 1999 | title = Income Inequality, Primary Care, and Health Indicators | url = | journal = The Journal of Family Practice | volume = 48 | issue = 4| pages = 275–284 }}</ref><ref name=":0">Kawachi, I., & Kennedy, B. P. (1999). Income inequality and health: pathways and mechanisms. ''Health Services Research'', 34(1 Pt 2), 215–227.</ref>
In China, for instance, the collapse of the [[Healthcare reform in China|Cooperative Medical System]] left many of the rural poor uninsured and unable to access the resources necessary to maintain good health<ref>Sun, X., Jackson, S., Carmichael, G. and Sleigh, A.C., 2009. Catastrophic medical payment and financial protection in rural China: evidence from the New Cooperative Medical Scheme in Shandong Province. Health economics, 18(1), pp.103-119.</ref>. Increases in the cost of medical treatment made healthcare increasingly unaffordable for these populations. This issue was further perpetuated by the rising [[income inequality]] in the Chinese population. Poor Chinese were often unable to undergo necessary hospitalization and failed to complete treatment regimens, resulting in poorer health outcomes.<ref name="Zhao, Zhongwei 2006">{{cite journal | author = Zhao Zhongwei | year = 2006 | title = Income Inequality, Unequal Health Care Access, and Mortality in China | url = | journal = Population and Development Review | volume = 32 | issue = 3| pages = 461–483 | doi=10.1111/j.1728-4457.2006.00133.x}}</ref>
Similarly, in Tanzania, it was demonstrated that wealthier families were far more likely to bring their children to a healthcare provider: a significant step towards stronger healthcare.<ref name=":2" /> Some scholars have noted that unequal income distribution itself can be a cause of poorer health for a society as a result of "underinvestment in social goods, such as public education and health care; disruption of social cohesion and the erosion of social capital".<ref name=":0" />
The role of socioeconomic status in health equity extends beyond simple monetary restrictions on an individual's purchasing power. In fact, [[social capital]] plays a significant role in the health of individuals and their communities. It has been shown that those who are better connected to the resources provided by the individuals and communities around them (those with more social capital) live longer lives.<ref>{{cite journal | author = House J. S., Landis K. R., Umberson D. | year = 1988 | title = Social relationships and health | url = | journal = Science | volume = 241 | issue = 4865| pages = 540–545 | doi=10.1126/science.3399889}}</ref> The [[Income segregation|segregation]] of communities on the basis of income occurs in nations worldwide and has a significant impact on quality of health as a result of a decrease in social capital for those trapped in poor neighborhoods.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Musterd S. |author2=De Winter M. | year = 1998 | title = Conditions for spatial segregation: some European perspectives | url = | journal = International Journal of Urban and Regional Research | volume = 22 | issue = 4| pages = 665–673 | doi = 10.1111/1468-2427.00168 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Musterd S | year = 2005 | title = Social and Ethnic Segregation in Europe: Levels, Causes, and Effects | url = | journal = Journal of Urban Affairs | volume = 27 | issue = 3| pages = 331–348 | doi = 10.1111/j.0735-2166.2005.00239.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Hajnal Z. L. | year = 1995 | title = The Nature of Concentrated Urban Poverty in Canada and the United States | url = | journal = Canadian Journal of Sociology | volume = 20 | issue = 4| pages = 497–528 | doi = 10.2307/3341855 | jstor = 3341855 }}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal | last1 = Kanbur | first1 = Ravi | last2 = Zhang | first2 = Xiaobo | author-link1 = Ravi Kanbur | title = Spatial inequality in education and health care in China | journal = China Economic Review | volume = 16 | issue = 2 | pages = 189–204 | doi = 10.1016/j.chieco.2005.02.002 | date = 2005 | ref = harv }}</ref> Social interventions, which seek to improve healthcare by enhancing the social resources of a community, are therefore an effective component of campaigns to improve a community's health. A 1998 epidemiological study'' ''showed that community healthcare approaches fared far better than individual approaches in the prevention of heart disease mortality.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Lomas Jonathan | year = 1998 | title = Social Capital and Health: Implications for Public Health and Epidemiology | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 47 | issue = 9| pages = 1181–1188 | doi=10.1016/s0277-9536(98)00190-7| citeseerx = 10.1.1.460.596 }}</ref>
Unconditional cash transfers for reducing poverty used by some programs in the developing world appear to lead to a reduction in the likelihood of being sick.<ref name="doi10.1002/14651858.CD011135.pub2">{{cite journal |title=Unconditional cash transfers for reducing poverty and vulnerabilities: effect on use of health services and health outcomes in low- and middle-income countries |journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |volume=11 |pages=CD011135 |year=2017 |doi= 10.1002/14651858.CD011135.pub2 |pmid=29139110 |last1=Pega |first1=Frank |last2=Liu |first2=Sze |last3=Walter |first3=Stefan |last4=Pabayo |first4=Roman |last5=Saith |first5=Ruhi |last6=Lhachimi |first6=Stefan }}</ref> Such evidence can guide resource allocations to effective interventions.
=== Education === Education is an important factor in healthcare utilization, though it is closely intertwined with economic status. An individual may not go to a medical professional or seek care if they don’t know the ills of their failure to do so, or the value of proper treatment.<ref name=":5" /> In Tajikistan, since the nation gained its independence, the likelihood of giving birth at home has increased rapidly among women with lower educational status. Education also has a significant impact on the quality of prenatal and maternal healthcare. Mothers with primary education consulted a doctor during pregnancy at significantly lower rates (72%) when compared to those with a secondary education (77%), technical training (88%) or a higher education (100%).<ref name=":4">{{cite journal | author = Falkingham Jane | year = 2003 | title = Inequality and Changes in Women's Use of Maternal Health-Care Services in Tajikistan | url = | journal = Studies in Family Planning | volume = 34 | issue = 1| pages = 32–43 | doi=10.1111/j.1728-4465.2003.00032.x| pmid = 12772444 }}</ref> There is also evidence for a correlation between socioeconomic status and health literacy; one study showed that wealthier Tanzanian families were more likely to recognize disease in their children than those that were coming from lower income backgrounds.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal |author1=Schellenberg J. A. |author2=Victora C. G. |author3=Mushi A. |author4=de Savigny D. |author5=Schellenberg D. |author6=Mshinda H. |author7=Bryce J. | year = 2003 | title = Inequities among the very poor: health care for children in rural southern Tanzania | url = | journal = The Lancet | volume = 361 | issue = 9357| pages = 561–566 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(03)12515-9 | pmid=12598141}}</ref>
== Spatial disparities in health == {{see also|Healthcare reform in China}}
For some populations, access to healthcare and health resources is physically limited, resulting in health inequities. For instance, an individual might be physically incapable of traveling the distances required to reach healthcare services, or long distances can make seeking regular care unappealing despite the potential benefits.<ref name=":5">Banerjee, A., Banerjee, A. V., & Duflo, E. (2011). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=em3_AgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Poor Economics: A Radical Rethinking of the Way to Fight Global Poverty]''. PublicAffairs.</ref> [[File:Global physician density map - WHO 2010.png|thumb|Global concentrations of healthcare resources, as depicted by the number of physicians per 100,000 individuals, by country.]]Costa Rica, for example, has demonstrable health spatial inequities with 12–14% of the population living in areas where healthcare is inaccessible. Inequity has decreased in some areas of the nation as a result of the work of healthcare reform programs, however those regions not served by the programs have experienced a slight increase in inequity.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Rosero-Bixby L | year = 2004 | title = Spatial access to health care in Costa Rica and its equity: a GIS-based study | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 58 | issue = 7| pages = 1271–1284 | doi = 10.1016/S0277-9536(03)00322-8 | pmid = 14759675 }}</ref>
China experienced a serious decrease in spatial health equity following the Chinese economic revolution in the 1980s as a result of the degradation of the [[Healthcare reform in China|Cooperative Medical System]] (CMS). The CMS provided an infrastructure for the delivery of healthcare to rural locations, as well as a framework to provide funding based upon communal contributions and government subsidies. In its absence, there was a significant decrease in the quantity of healthcare professionals (35.9%), as well as functioning clinics (from 71% to 55% of villages over 14 years) in rural areas, resulting in inequitable healthcare for rural populations.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Liu Y. |author2=Hsiao W. C. |author3=Eggleston K. | year = 1999 | title = Equity in health and health care: the Chinese experience | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 49 | issue = 10| pages = 1349–1356 | doi = 10.1016/S0277-9536(99)00207-5 }}</ref> The significant poverty experienced by rural workers (some earning less than 1 USD per day) further limits access to healthcare, and results in malnutrition and poor general hygiene, compounding the loss of healthcare resources.<ref name="Zhao, Zhongwei 2006"/> The loss of the CMS has had noticeable impacts on life expectancy, with rural regions such as areas of Western China experiencing significantly lower life expectancies.<ref>Qian Jiwei. (n.d.). ''Regional Inequality in Healthcare in China''. East Asian Institute, National University of Singapore.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wang H, Xu T, Xu J | year = 2007 | title = Factors Contributing to High Costs and Inequality in China's Health Care System | url = | journal = JAMA | volume = 298 | issue = 16| pages = 1928–1930 | doi=10.1001/jama.298.16.1928 | pmid=17954544}}</ref>
Similarly, populations in rural Tajikistan experience spatial health inequities. A study by [[Jane Falkingham]] noted that physical access to healthcare was one of the primary factors influencing quality of maternal healthcare. Further, many women in rural areas of the country did not have adequate access to healthcare resources, resulting in poor maternal and neonatal care. These rural women were, for instance, far more likely to give birth in their homes without medical oversight.<ref name=":4" />
==Ethnic and racial disparities== {{see also|Race and health}}
Along with the socioeconomic factor of health disparities, race is another key factor. The United States historically had large disparities in health and access to adequate healthcare between races, and current evidence supports the notion that [[Race and health in the United States|these racially centered disparities continue to exist]] and are a significant social health issue.<ref name="Weinick">{{cite journal |author1=Weinick R. M. |author2=Zuvekas S. H. |author3=Cohen J. W. | year = 2000 | title = Racial and ethnic differences in access to and use of health care services, 1977 to 1996. Medical care research and review | url = | journal = MCRR | volume = 57 | issue = Suppl 1| pages = 36–54 }}</ref> The disparities in access to adequate healthcare include differences in the quality of care based on race and overall insurance coverage based on race. A 2002 study in the ''[[Journal of the American Medical Association]]'' identifies race as a significant determinant in the level of quality of care, with blacks receiving lower quality care than their white counterparts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schneider|first=Eric C.|date=2002-03-13|title=Racial Disparities in the Quality of Care for Enrollees in Medicare Managed Care|url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/194724|journal=JAMA|language=en|volume=287|issue=10|doi=10.1001/jama.287.10.1288|issn=0098-7484|page=1288}}</ref> This is in part because members of ethnic minorities such as African Americans are either earning low incomes, or living below the poverty line. In a 2007 Census Bureau, African American families made an average of $33,916, while their white counterparts made an average of $54,920.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url = http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sort=RELEVANCE&inPS=true&prodId=GVRL&userGroupName=pcc&tabID=T003&searchId=R1&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&contentSegment=&searchType=BasicSearchForm&currentPosition=4&contentSet=GALE%7CCX1838000217&&docId=GALE|CX1838000217&docType=GALE|title = African American Poverty Leads to Health Disparities|date = 2010|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Gale Virtual Reference Library|publisher = UXL}}</ref> Due to a lack of affordable health care, the African American death rate reveals that African Americans have a higher rate of dying from treatable or preventable causes. According to a study conducted in 2005 by the Office of Minority Health—a U.S. Department of Health—African American men were 30% more likely than white men to die from heart disease.<ref name=":6" /> Also African American women were 34% more likely to die from breast cancer than their white counterparts.<ref name=":6" />
There are also considerable racial disparities in access to insurance coverage, with ethnic minorities generally having less insurance coverage than non-ethnic minorities. For example, Hispanic Americans tend to have less insurance coverage than white Americans and as a result receive less regular medical care. The level of insurance coverage is directly correlated with access to healthcare including preventative and [[ambulatory]] care.<ref name="Weinick" /> A 2010 study on racial and ethnic disparities in health done by the [[Institute of Medicine]] has shown that the aforementioned disparities cannot solely be accounted for in terms of certain demographic characteristics like: insurance status, household income, education, age, geographic location and quality of living conditions. Even when the researchers corrected for these factors, the disparities persist.<ref name="unequal">{{cite journal | author = Nelson A | year = 2002 | title = Unequal treatment: confronting racial and ethnic disparities in health care | url =https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2594273/pdf/jnma00325-0024.pdf | journal = Journal of the National Medical Association | volume = 94 | issue = | page = 8 }}</ref> Slavery has contributed to [[Race and health in the United States#African-Americans|disparate health outcomes for generations of African Americans in the United States]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gaskins|first1=Darrell J.|title=RACIAL DISPARITIES IN HEALTH AND WEALTH: THE EFFECTS OF SLAVERY AND PAST DISCRIMINATION|journal=Review of Black Political Economy|date=Spring 2005|volume=32|issue=America: History & Life, EBSCOhost|page=95|accessdate=|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1007/s12114-005-1007-9}}</ref>
Ethnic health inequities also appear in nations across the African continent. A survey of the child mortality of major ethnic groups across 11 African nations (Central African Republic, Côte d'Ivoire, Ghana, Kenya, Mali, Namibia, Niger, Rwanda, Senegal, Uganda, and Zambia) was published in 2000 by the WHO. The study described the presence of significant ethnic parities in the child mortality rates among children younger than 5 years old, as well as in education and vaccine use.<ref name=pmid10686731>{{cite journal |pmid=10686731 |pmc=2560588 |year=2000 |author1=Brockerhoff |first1=M |title=Inequality of child mortality among ethnic groups in sub-Saharan Africa |journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization |volume=78 |issue=1 |pages=30–41 |last2=Hewett |first2=P }}</ref> In South Africa, the legacy of apartheid still manifests itself as a differential access to social services, including healthcare based upon race and social class, and the resultant health inequities.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Bloom G. |author2=McIntyre D. | year = 1998 | title = Towards equity in health in an unequal society | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 47 | issue = 10| pages = 1529–1538 | doi = 10.1016/S0277-9536(98)00233-0 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=McIntyre D. |author2=Gilson L. | year = 2002 | title = Putting equity in health back onto the social policy agenda: experience from South Africa | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 54 | issue = 11| pages = 1637–1656 | doi = 10.1016/S0277-9536(01)00332-X }}</ref> Further, evidence suggests systematic disregard of indigenous populations in a number of countries. The Pygmys of Congo, for instance, are excluded from government health programs, discriminated against during public health campaigns, and receive poorer overall healthcare.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Ohenjo N. |author2=Willis R. |author3=Jackson D. |author4=Nettleton C. |author5=Good K. |author6=Mugarura B. | year = 2006 | title = Health of Indigenous people in Africa | url = | journal = The Lancet | volume = 367 | issue = 9526| pages = 1937–1946 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(06)68849-1 |pmid=16765763 }}</ref>
In a survey of five European countries (Sweden, Switzerland, the UK, Italy, and France), a 1995 survey noted that only Sweden provided access to translators for 100% of those who needed it, while the other countries lacked this service potentially compromising healthcare to non-native populations. Given that non-natives composed a considerable section of these nations (6%, 17%, 3%, 1%, and 6% respectively), this could have significant detrimental effects on the health equity of the nation. In France, an older study noted significant differences in access to healthcare between native French populations, and non-French/migrant populations based upon health expenditure; however this was not fully independent of poorer economic and working conditions experienced by these populations.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Bollini P. |author2=Siem H. | year = 1995 | title = No real progress towards equity: Health of migrants and ethnic minorities on the eve of the year 2000 | url = | journal = Social Science & Medicine | volume = 41 | issue = 6| pages = 819–828 | doi = 10.1016/0277-9536(94)00386-8 }}</ref>
A 1996 study of race-based health inequity in Australia revealed that [[Indigenous health in Australia|Aborigines experienced higher rates of mortality]] than non-Aborigine populations. Aborigine populations experienced 10 times greater mortality in the 30–40 age range; 2.5 times greater infant mortality rate, and 3 times greater age standardized mortality rate. Rates of diarrheal diseases and tuberculosis are also significantly greater in this population (16 and 15 times greater respectively), which is indicative of the poor healthcare of this ethnic group. At this point in time, the parities in life expectancy at birth between indigenous and non-indigenous peoples were highest in Australia, when compared to the US, Canada and New Zealand.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Mooney G | year = 1996 | title = And now for vertical equity? Some concerns arising from Aboriginal health in Australia | url = | journal = Health Economics | volume = 5 | issue = 2| pages = 99–103 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1099-1050(199603)5:2<99::AID-HEC193>3.0.CO;2-N | pmid = 8733102 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Anderson I. |author2=Crengle S. |author3=Leialoha Kamaka M. |author4=Chen T.-H. |author5=Palafox N. |author6=Jackson-Pulver L. | year = 2006 | title = Indigenous health in Australia, New Zealand, and the Pacific | url = | journal = The Lancet | volume = 367 | issue = 9524| pages = 1775–1785 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(06)68773-4 |pmid=16731273 }}</ref> In South America, indigenous populations faced similarly poor health outcomes with maternal and infant mortality rates that were significantly higher (up to 3 to 4 times greater) than the national average.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Montenegro R. A. |author2=Stephens C. | year = 2006 | title = Indigenous health in Latin America and the Caribbean | url = | journal = The Lancet | volume = 367 | issue = 9525| pages = 1859–1869 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(06)68808-9 |pmid=16753489 }}</ref> The same pattern of poor indigenous healthcare continues in India, where indigenous groups were shown to experience greater mortality at most stages of life, even when corrected for environmental effects.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Subramanian S. V. |author2=Smith G. D. |author3=Subramanyam M. | year = 2006 | title = Indigenous Health and Socioeconomic Status in India | url = | journal = PLoS Med | volume = 3 | issue = 10| page = e421 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pmed.0030421 |pmid=17076556 |pmc=1621109 }}</ref>
== LGBT health disparities == {{see also|LGBT issues in medicine}}
Sexuality is a basis of health discrimination and inequity throughout the world. [[Homosexual]], [[bisexual]], [[transgender]], and [[Gender variance|gender-variant]] populations around the world experience a range of health problems related to their [[Human sexuality|sexuality]] and [[gender identity]],<ref>Burke, Jill. "Understanding the GLBT community." ASHA Leader 20 Jan. 2009: 4+. Communications and Mass Media Collection.</ref><ref>Gochman, David S. (1997). ''Handbook of health behavior research''. [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]. pp. 145–147. {{ISBN|9780306454431}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Trettin S., Moses-Kolko E.L., Wisner K.L. | year = 2006 | title = Lesbian perinatal depression and the heterosexism that affects knowledge about this minority population | url = | journal = Archives of Women's Mental Health | volume = 9 | issue = 2| pages = 67–73 | doi = 10.1089/jwh.2010.2328 | pmid = 21668380 | pmc = 3130513 }}</ref><ref name=":04">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(17)30837-1 |pmid=28379143 |title=Health and rights challenges for China's LGBT community |journal=The Lancet |volume=389 |issue=10076 |pages=1286 |year=2017 |last1=Burki |first1=Talha }}</ref> some of which are complicated further by limited research.
In spite of recent advances, LGBT populations in China, India, and Chile continue to face significant discrimination and barriers to care.<ref name=":04" /><ref>Brocchetto M. “[http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/26/americas/lgbt-rights-in-the-americas/index.html Being gay in Latin America: Legal but deadly]”. ''CNN''. Updated March 3, 2017 <nowiki>http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/26/americas/lgbt-rights-in-the-americas/index.html</nowiki>. Retrieved September 30, 2017.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/06/healthcare-distant-india-transgenders-201461882414495902.html|title=Indian transgender healthcare challenges|last=Soumya|first=Elizabeth Soumya Elizabeth|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-10-01}}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) recognizes that there is inadequate research data about the effects of LGBT discrimination on morbidity and mortality rates in the patient population. In addition, retrospective epidemiological studies on LGBT populations are difficult to conduct as a result of the practice that sexual orientation is not noted on death certificates.<ref name=":112"/> WHO has proposed that more research about the LGBT patient population is needed  for improved understanding of its  unique health needs and barriers to accessing care.<ref>CD52/18: Addressing the causes of disparities in health service access and utilization for lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans (LGBT) persons. 2013. <nowiki>http://www.who.int/hiv/pub/populations/lgbt_paper/en/</nowiki></ref>
Recognizing the need for LGBT healthcare research, the Director of the [[National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities]] (NIMHD) at the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] designated sexual and gender minorities (SGMs) as a health disparity population for NIH research in October 2016.<ref name=":14">Meads, C.; Pennant, M.; McManus, J.; Bayliss, S. (2011). "[https://bura.brunel.ac.uk/bitstream/2438/9756/1/Fulltext.pdf A systematic review of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender health in the West Midlands Region of the UK compared to published UK research]". Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref> For the purposes of this designation, the Director defines SGM as "encompass[ing] lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender populations, as well as those whose sexual orientation, gender identity and expressions, or reproductive development varies from traditional, societal, cultural, or physiological norms".<ref name=":14" /> This designation has prioritized research into the extent, cause, and potential mitigation of health disparities among SGM populations within the larger LGBT community.
While many aspects of LGBT health disparities are heretofore uninvestigated, at this stage, it is known that one of the main forms of healthcare discrimination  [[LGBT]] individuals face is discrimination from healthcare workers or institutions themselves.<ref name=":24">Kalra G.,Ventriglio A., Bhugra D. [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.3109/09540261.2015.1094032 Sexuality and mental health: Issues and what next?] (2015) ''International Review of Psychiatry'' Vol. 27 , Iss. 5.</ref><ref name="King 70">{{Cite journal|last=King|first=Michael|last2=Semlyen|first2=Joanna|last3=Tai|first3=Sharon See|last4=Killaspy|first4=Helen|last5=Osborn|first5=David|last6=Popelyuk|first6=Dmitri|last7=Nazareth|first7=Irwin|date=2008-08-18|title=A systematic review of mental disorder, suicide, and deliberate self harm in lesbian, gay and bisexual people |journal=BMC Psychiatry|volume=8|pages=70|doi=10.1186/1471-244X-8-70|pmid=18706118|pmc=2533652|issn=1471-244X}}</ref> A systematic literature review of publications in English and Portuguese from 2004–2014 demonstrate significant difficulties in accessing care secondary to discrimination and homophobia from healthcare professionals.<ref name=":33">{{Cite journal|last=Alencar Albuquerque|first=Grayce|last2=de Lima Garcia|first2=Cintia|last3=da Silva Quirino|first3=Glauberto|last4=Alves|first4=Maria Juscinaide Henrique|last5=Belém|first5=Jameson Moreira|last6=dos Santos Figueiredo|first6=Francisco Winter|last7=da Silva Paiva|first7=Laércio|last8=do Nascimento|first8=Vânia Barbosa|last9=da Silva Maciel|first9=Érika|date=2016-01-14|title=Access to health services by lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender persons: systematic literature review|journal=BMC International Health and Human Rights|volume=16|pages=2|doi=10.1186/s12914-015-0072-9|issn=1472-698X|pmc=4714514|pmid=26769484}}</ref> This discrimination can take the form of verbal abuse, disrespectful conduct, refusal of care, the withholding of health information,  inadequate treatment, and outright violence.<ref name=":33" /><ref name=":43">IOM (Institute of Medicine). 2011. ''The Health of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender People: Building a Foundation for Better Understanding''. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press.</ref> In a study analyzing the quality of healthcare for South African men who have sex with men ([[Men who have sex with men|MSM]]), researchers interviewed a cohort of individuals about their health experiences, finding that MSM who identified as homosexual felt their access to healthcare was limited due to an inability to find clinics employing healthcare workers who did not discriminate against their sexuality.<ref name=pmid19028941>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/sti.2008.031567 |pmid=19028941 |pmc=2780345 |title="They see you as a different thing": The experiences of men who have sex with men with healthcare workers in South African township communities |journal=Sexually Transmitted Infections |volume=84 |issue=6 |pages=430–3 |year=2008 |last1=Lane |first1=T |last2=Mogale |first2=T |last3=Struthers |first3=H |last4=McIntyre |first4=J |last5=Kegeles |first5=S M }}</ref> They also reportedly faced "homophobic verbal harassment from healthcare workers when presenting for [[Sexually transmitted disease|STI]] treatment".<ref name=pmid19028941/> Further, MSM who did not feel comfortable disclosing their sexual activity to healthcare workers failed to identify as homosexuals, which limited the quality of the treatment they received.<ref name=pmid19028941/>
Additionally, members of the LGBT community contend with health care disparities due, in part, to lack of provider training and awareness of the population’s healthcare needs.<ref name=":43" /> Studies regarding patient-provider communication in the LGBT patient community show that providers themselves report a significant lack of awareness regarding the health issues LGBT-identifying patients face.<ref name=":43" /> As a component of this fact, medical schools do not focus much attention on LGBT health issues in their curriculum; the LGBT-related topics that are discussed tend to be limited to HIV/AIDS, sexual orientation, and gender identity.<ref name=":43" />
Among LGBT-identifying individuals, transgender individuals face especially significant barriers to treatment. Many countries still do not have [[Legal recognition of non-binary gender|legal recognition of transgender or non-binary gender]] individuals leading to placement in mis-gendered hospital wards and medical discrimination.<ref name=":63">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2016/rights-in-transition|title=Rights in Transition|date=2016-01-06|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=2017-10-01|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":72">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-world-health-lgbt/transgender-people-face-challenges-for-adequate-health-care-study-idUSKCN0Z30S0|title=Transgender people face challenges for adequate health care: study|date=2016-06-17|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-10-01}}</ref> Seventeen European states mandate sterilization of individuals who seek recognition of a gender identity that diverges from their birth gender.<ref name=":72" /> In addition to many of the same barriers as the rest of the LGBT community, a WHO bulletin points out that globally, transgender individuals often also face a higher disease burden.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Ensuring an inclusive global health agenda for transgender people|url=http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/95/2/16-183913/en/|journal=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|doi=10.2471/BLT.16.183913|pmid=28250518|volume=95|issue=2|year=2017|pages=154–156|author=Thomas Rebekah, Pega Frank, Khosla Rajat, Verster Annette, Hana Tommy, Say Lale|pmc=5327942}}</ref> A 2010 survey of transgender and gender-variant people in the United States revealed that transgender individuals faced a significant level of discrimination.<ref name=":82">Jaime M. Grant, Lisa A. Mottet, & Justin Tanis. (2010). ''National Transgender Discrimination Survey Report on health and health care''. National Gay and Lesbian Task Force.</ref> The survey indicated that 19% of individuals experienced a healthcare worker refusing care because of their gender, 28% faced harassment from a healthcare worker, 2% encountered violence, and 50% saw a doctor who was not able or qualified to provide transgender-sensitive care.<ref name=":82" /> In Kuwait, there have been reports of transgender individuals being reported to legal authorities by medical professionals, preventing safe access to care.<ref name=":63" /> An updated version of the U.S. survey from 2015 showed little change in terms of healthcare experiences for transgender and gender variant individuals. The updated survey revealed that 23% of individuals reported not seeking necessary medical care out of fear of discrimination, and 33% of individuals who had been to a doctor within a year of taking the survey reported negative encounters with medical professionals related to their transgender status.<ref name=":92">James, S. E., Herman, J. L., Rankin, S., Keisling, M., Mottet, L., & Anafi, M. (2016). The Report of the 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey. Washington, DC: National Center for Transgender Equality.{{pn|date=April 2018}}</ref>
The stigmatization represented particularly in the transgender population  creates a health disparity for LGBT individuals with regard to [[mental health]].<ref name=":24" /> The LGBT community is at increased risk for psychosocial distress, mental health complications, suicidality, homelessness, and [[substance abuse]], often complicated by access-based under-utilization or fear of health services.<ref name=":24" /><ref name="King 70"/><ref>Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion. "Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Health". ''HealthyPeople.gov''. Retrieved September 16, 2017.</ref> Transgender and gender-variant individuals have been found to experience higher rates of mental health disparity than LGB individuals. According to the 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey, for example, 39% of respondents reported serious psychological distress, compared to 5% of the general population.<ref name=":92" />
These mental health facts are informed by a history of anti-LGBT bias in health care.<ref name=":102">''Understanding the Health Needs of LGBT People''. (March 2016) National LGBT Health Education Center. The Fenway Institute.</ref> The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders ([[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM]]) listed homosexuality as a disorder until 1973; transgender status was listed as a disorder until 2012.<ref name=":102" /> This was amended in 2013 with the [[DSM-5]] when "gender identity disorder" was replaced with "[[gender dysphoria]]", reflecting that simply identifying as transgender is not itself pathological and that the diagnosis is instead for the distress a transgender person may experience as a result of the discordance between assigned gender and gender identity.<ref>Parekh, Ranna (February 2016). "What Is Gender Dysphoria?". ''American Psychiatric Association''. Retrieved September 16, 2017.</ref>
LGBT health issues have received disproportionately low levels of medical research, leading to difficulties in assessing appropriate strategies for LGBT treatment. For instance, a review of medical literature regarding LGBT patients revealed that there are significant gaps in the medical understanding of cervical cancer in lesbian and bisexual individuals<ref name=":112">{{Cite journal|last=Tracy|first=J. Kathleen|last2=Lydecker|first2=Alison D.|last3=Ireland|first3=Lynda|date=2010-01-24|title=Barriers to Cervical Cancer Screening Among Lesbians |journal=Journal of Women's Health|volume=19|issue=2|pages=229–237|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1393|pmid=20095905|issn=1540-9996|pmc=2834453}}</ref> it is unclear whether its prevalence in this community is a result of probability or some other preventable cause. For example, LGBT people report poorer cancer care experiences.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hulbert-Williams|first=N. J.|last2=Plumpton|first2=C.o.|last3=Flowers|first3=P.|last4=McHugh|first4=R.|last5=Neal|first5=R.d.|last6=Semlyen|first6=J.|last7=Storey|first7=L.|date=2017-07-01|title=The cancer care experiences of gay, lesbian and bisexual patients: A secondary analysis of data from the UK Cancer Patient Experience Survey |journal=European Journal of Cancer Care|language=en|volume=26|issue=4|pages=n/a|doi=10.1111/ecc.12670|pmid=28239936|issn=1365-2354}}</ref> It is incorrectly assumed that LGBT women have a lower incidence of cervical cancer than their heterosexual counterparts, resulting in lower rates of screening.<ref name=":112" />  Such findings illustrate the need for continued research focused on the circumstances and needs of LGBT individuals and the inclusion in policy frameworks of sexual orientation and gender identity as social determinants of health.<ref name=pmid25602894>{{cite journal |pmid=25602894 |title=The case for the World Health Organization's Commission on Social Determinants of Health to address gender identity |journal=American Journal of Public Health |volume=105 |issue=3 |pages=e58–62 |year=2015 |last1=Pega |first1=Frank |last2=Veale |first2=Jaimie |doi=10.2105/ajph.2014.302373 |pmc=4330845}}</ref>
A June 2017 review sponsored by the European commission as part of a larger project to identify and diminish health inequities, found that LGB are at higher risk of some cancers and that LGBTI were at higher risk of mental illness, and that these risks were not adequately addressed. The causes of health inequities were, according to the review, "i) cultural and social norms that preference and prioritise heterosexuality; ii) minority stress associated with sexual orientation, gender identity and sex characteristics; iii) victimisation; iv) discrimination (individual and institutional), and; v) stigma."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Health4LGBTI |title=State-of-the-art study focusing on the health inequalities faced by LGBTI people D1.1 State-of-the-Art Synthesis Report (SSR) June, 2017 |url=https://ec.europa.eu/health/sites/health/files/social_determinants/docs/stateofart_report_en.pdf |date=June 2017}}</ref>
== Sex and gender in healthcare equity == {{See also|Gender disparities in health}}
=== Sex and gender in medicine === Both gender and sex are significant factors that influence health. '''[[Sex]]''' is characterized by female and male biological differences in regards to gene expression, hormonal concentration, and anatomical characteristics.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Regitz-Zagrosek|first=Vera|date=July 2012|title=Sex and gender differences in health|journal=EMBO Reports|volume=13|issue=7|pages=596–603|doi=10.1038/embor.2012.87|issn=1469-221X|pmc=3388783|pmid=22699937}}</ref> '''[[Gender]]''' is an expression of behavior and lifestyle choices. Both sex and gender inform each other, and it is important to note that differences between the two genders influence disease manifestation and associated healthcare approaches.<ref name=":02" /> Understanding how the interaction of sex and gender contributes to disparity in the context of health allows providers to ensure quality outcomes for patients. This interaction is complicated by the difficulty of distinguishing between sex and gender given their intertwined nature; sex modifies gender, and gender can modify sex, thereby impacting health.<ref name=":02" />  Sex and gender can both be considered sources of health disparity; both contribute to men and women’s susceptibility to various health conditions, including cardiovascular disease and autoimmune disorders.<ref name=":02" />
=== Health disparities in the male population === As sex and gender are inextricably linked in day-to-day life, their union is apparent in medicine. Gender and sex are both components of health disparity in the male population. In non-Western regions, males tend to have a health advantage over women due to gender discrimination, evidenced by infanticide, early marriage, and domestic abuse for females.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fikree|first=FF|last2=Pasha|first2=O|date=2004|title=Role of gender in health disparity: the South Asian context|url=|journal=BMJ: British Medical Journal|volume=328 | issue = 7443 |pages=823–826|via=|doi=10.1136/bmj.328.7443.823|pmid=15070642|pmc=383384}}</ref> In most regions of the world, the mortality rate is higher for adult men than for adult women; for example, adult men suffer from fatal illnesses with more frequency than females.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/child-adolescenthealth/New_Publications/ADH/WHO_FCH_CAH_00.7.pdf|title=What about boys? A literature review on the health and development of adolescent boys|last=Barker|first=G|date=|website=WHO|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050411094056/http://www.who.int/child%2Dadolescenthealth/New_Publications/ADH/WHO_FCH_CAH_00.7.pdf|archive-date=2005-04-11|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> The leading causes of the higher male death rate are accidents, injuries, violence, and cardiovascular diseases. In a number of countries, males also face a heightened risk of mortality as a result of behavior and greater propensity for violence.<ref name=":12" />
Physicians tend to offer invasive procedures to male patients more than female patients.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kent|first=Jennifer|last2=Patel|first2=Vinisha|last3=Varela|first3=Natalie|date=2012|title=Gender Disparities in Healthcare|url=|journal=Mount Sinai Journal of Medicine|volume=79|issue=5|pages=555–559|via=|doi=10.1002/msj.21336|pmid=22976361}}</ref> Furthermore, men are more likely to smoke than women and experience smoking-related health complications later in life as a result; this trend is also observed in regard to other substances, such as marijuana, in Jamaica, where the rate of use is 2–3 times more for men than women.<ref name=":12" /> Lastly, men are more likely to have severe chronic conditions and a lower life expectancy than women in the United States.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Courtenay|first=Will H|date=2000-05-16|title=Constructions of masculinity and their influence on men's well-being: a theory of gender and health|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=50|issue=10|pages=1385–1401|doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(99)00390-1|citeseerx=10.1.1.462.4452}}</ref>
=== Health disparities in the female population === Gender and sex are also components of health disparity in the female population. The 2012 [[World Development Report]] (WDR) noted that women in [[Developing country|developing nations]] experience greater [[mortality rate]]s than men in developing nations.<ref>World Bank. (2012). World Development Report on Gender Equality and Development.</ref> Additionally, women in developing countries have a much higher risk of [[maternal death]] than those in developed countries. The highest risk of dying during childbirth is 1 in 6 in Afghanistan and Sierra Leone, compared to nearly 1 in 30,000 in Sweden—a disparity that is much greater than that for neonatal or [[child mortality]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ronsmans|first=Carine|last2=Graham|first2=Wendy J|title=Maternal mortality: who, when, where, and why |journal=The Lancet|volume=368|issue=9542|pages=1189–1200|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(06)69380-x|pmid=17011946|year=2006}}</ref>
While women in the United States tend to live longer than men, they generally are of lower [[socioeconomic status]] (SES) and therefore have more barriers to accessing healthcare.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Read|first=Jen'nan Ghazal|last2=Gorman|first2=Bridget K.|date=2010|title=Gender and Health Inequality |journal=Annual Review of Sociology|volume=36|issue=1|pages=371–386|doi=10.1146/annurev.soc.012809.102535}}</ref> Being of lower SES also tends to increase societal pressures, which can lead to higher rates of [[Depression (differential diagnoses)|depression]] and chronic stress and, in turn, negatively impact health.<ref name=":22" /> Women are also more likely than men to suffer from [[Sexual violence|sexual]] or [[Intimate partner violence|intimate-partner violence]] both in the United States and worldwide. In Europe, women who grew up in poverty are more likely to have lower muscle strength and higher disability in old age.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cheval|first=Boris et al.|date=2018-02-20|title=Association of early- and adult-life socioeconomic circumstances with muscle strength in older age|journal=Age and Ageing|language=en|volume=47|issue=3|pages=398–407|doi=10.1093/ageing/afy003|pmid=29471364|issn=0002-0729}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Landös|first=Aljoscha et al.|title=Childhood socioeconomic circumstances and disability trajectories in older men and women: a European cohort study|journal=European Journal of Public Health|language=en|volume=|pages=|doi=10.1093/eurpub/cky166|year=2018}}</ref>
Women have better access to healthcare in the United States than they do in many other places in the world.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vaidya|first=Varun|last2=Partha|first2=Gautam|last3=Karmakar|first3=Monita|date=2011-11-14|title=Gender Differences in Utilization of Preventive Care Services in the United States |journal=Journal of Women's Health|volume=21|issue=2|pages=140–145|doi=10.1089/jwh.2011.2876|pmid=22081983|issn=1540-9996}}</ref> In one population study conducted in Harlem, New York, 86% of women reported having privatized or publicly assisted health insurance, while only 74% of men reported having any health insurance. This trend is representative of the general population of the United States.<ref name="Merzel2">{{cite journal|author=Merzel C|year=2000|title=Gender differences in health care access indicators in an urban, low-income community|url=|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=90|issue=6|pages=909–916|doi=10.2105/ajph.90.6.909|pmid=10846508|pmc=1446268}}</ref>
In addition, women's pain tends to be treated less seriously and initially ignored by clinicians when compared to their treatment of men's pain complaints.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hoffmann|first=Diane E.|last2=Tarzian|first2=Anita J.|date=2001-03-01|title=The Girl Who Cried Pain: A Bias against Women in the Treatment of Pain |journal=The Journal of Law, Medicine & Ethics|language=en|volume=28|issue=4_suppl|pages=13–27|doi=10.1111/j.1748-720X.2001.tb00037.x|issn=1073-1105}}</ref> Historically, women have not been included in the design or practice of [[clinical trial]]s, which has slowed the understanding of women's reactions to medications and created a research gap. This has led to post-approval [[Adverse effect|adverse events]] among women, resulting in several drugs being pulled from the market. However, the clinical research industry is aware of the problem, and has made progress in correcting it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Katherine A.|last2=Mager|first2=Natalie A. Dipietro|date=2016|title=Women's involvement in clinical trials: historical perspective and future implications|journal=Pharmacy Practice|volume=14|issue=1|doi=10.18549/PharmPract.2016.01.708|issn=1885-642X|pmc=4800017|pmid=27011778|page=708}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://orwh.od.nih.gov/clinical/women-and-minorities/|title=Including Women and Minorities in Clinical Research {{!}} ORWH|last=ORWH|website=orwh.od.nih.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref>
=== Cultural factors === Health disparities are also due in part to cultural factors that involve practices based not only on sex, but also gender status. For example, in [[China]], health disparities have distinguished medical treatment for men and women due to the cultural phenomenon of preference for male children.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mu|first=Ren|last2=Zhang|first2=Xiaobo|date=2011-01-01|title=Why does the Great Chinese Famine affect the male and female survivors differently? Mortality selection versus son preference|journal=Economics & Human Biology|volume=9|issue=1|pages=92–105|doi=10.1016/j.ehb.2010.07.003|pmid=20732838}}</ref> Recently, gender-based disparities have decreased as females have begun to receive higher-quality care.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Anson O.|author2=Sun S.|year=2002|title=Gender and health in rural China: evidence from HeBei province|url=|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=55|issue=6|pages=1039–1054|doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(01)00227-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Yu M.-Y.|author2=Sarri R.|year=1997|title=Women's health status and gender inequality in China|url=|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=45|issue=12|pages=1885–1898|doi=10.1016/S0277-9536(97)00127-5}}</ref> Additionally, a girl’s chances of survival are impacted by the presence of a male sibling; while girls do have the same chance of survival as boys if they are the oldest girl, they have a higher probability of being [[Abortion|aborted]] or dying young if they have an older sister.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gupta|first=Monica Das|date=2005-09-01|title=Explaining Asia's "Missing Women": A New Look at the Data |journal=Population and Development Review|language=en|volume=31|issue=3|pages=529–535|doi=10.1111/j.1728-4457.2005.00082.x|issn=1728-4457}}</ref>
In [[India]], gender-based health inequities are apparent in early childhood. Many families provide better nutrition for boys in the interest of maximizing future productivity given that boys are generally seen as [[Breadwinner model|breadwinners]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Behrman J. R.|year=1988|title=Intrahousehold Allocation of Nutrients in Rural India: Are Boys Favored? Do Parents Exhibit Inequality Aversion?|url=|journal=Oxford Economic Papers|volume=40|issue=1|pages=32–54}}</ref> In addition, boys receive better care than girls and are hospitalized at a greater rate. The magnitude of these disparities increases with the severity of [[Poverty in India|poverty]] in a given population.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Asfaw A.|author2=Lamanna F.|author3=Klasen S.|year=2010|title=Gender gap in parents' financing strategy for hospitalization of their children: evidence from India|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1229180|journal=Health Economics|volume=19|issue=3|pages=265–279|doi=10.1002/hec.1468|pmid=19267357|type=Submitted manuscript}}</ref>
Additionally, the cultural practice of [[female genital mutilation]] (FGM) is known to impact women's health, though is difficult to know the worldwide extent of this practice. While generally thought of as a [[Sub-Saharan Africa]]n practice, it may have roots in the [[Middle East]] as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uwer|first=Thomas von der Osten-Sacken ; Thomas|date=2007-01-01|title=Is Female Genital Mutilation an Islamic Problem?|url=http://www.meforum.org/1629/is-female-genital-mutilation-an-islamic-problem/|journal=Middle East Quarterly|language=en-US}}</ref> The estimated 3 million girls who are subjected to FGM each year potentially suffer both immediate and lifelong negative effects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/topics/fgm/prevalence/en/|title=Female genital mutilation (FGM)|website=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref> Immediately following FGM, girls commonly experience excessive bleeding and [[Urinary retention|urine retention]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rhmjournal.org.uk/2015/03/immediate-health-consequences-of-female-genital-mutilation/|title=Immediate health consequences of female genital mutilation {{!}} Reproductive Health Matters: reproductive & sexual health and rights|date=2015-03-01|work=Reproductive Health Matters: reproductive & sexual health and rights|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en-GB}}</ref> Long-term consequences include [[urinary tract infection]]s, [[bacterial vaginosis]], [[Dyspareunia|pain during intercourse]], and difficulties in childbirth that include prolonged labor, vaginal tears, and excessive bleeding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kunnskapssenteret.no/en/publications/gynecological-consequences-of-female-genital-mutilation-cutting-fgm-c|title=Gynecological consequences of female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C)|website=Nasjonalt kunnskapssenter for helsetjenesten|language=en|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berg|first=Rigmor|last2=Underland|first2=Vigdis|date=June 10, 2013|title=The Obstetric Consequences of Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/ogi/2013/496564/abs/|journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology International|volume=2013|doi=10.1155/2013/496564|pmid=23878544|pmc=3710629|via=|pages=1–15}}</ref> Women who have undergone FGM also have higher rates of [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) and [[Herpes simplex virus|herpes simplex virus 2]] (HSV2) than women who have not.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Behrendt|first=Alice|last2=Moritz|first2=Steffen|date=2005-05-01|title=Posttraumatic Stress Disorder and Memory Problems After Female Genital Mutilation |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry|volume=162|issue=5|pages=1000–1002|doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.162.5.1000|pmid=15863806|issn=0002-953X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morison|first=Linda|last2=Scherf|first2=Caroline|last3=Ekpo|first3=Gloria|last4=Paine|first4=Katie|last5=West|first5=Beryl|last6=Coleman|first6=Rosalind|last7=Walraven|first7=Gijs|date=2001-08-01|title=The long-term reproductive health consequences of female genital cutting in rural Gambia: a community-based survey |journal=Tropical Medicine & International Health|language=en|volume=6|issue=8|pages=643–653|doi=10.1046/j.1365-3156.2001.00749.x|issn=1365-3156|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1046/j.1365-3156.2001.00749.x}}</ref>
== Health inequality and environmental influence == Minority populations have increased exposure to environmental hazards that include lack of neighborhood resources, structural and community factors as well as residential segregation that result in a cycle of disease and stress.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gee|first=GC|author2=Payne-Sturges D.|title=Environmental health disparities: A framework integrating psychosocial and environmental concepts. Environmental Health Perspectives|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=112|pages=1645–1653|doi=10.1289/ehp.7074|date=2004|issue=17|pmid=15579407|pmc=1253653}}</ref> The environment that surrounds us can influence individual behaviors and lead to poor health choices and therefore outcomes.<ref name="Woolf 1852–1859">{{cite journal|last=Woolf|first=S. H.|author2=Braveman, P.|title=Where Health Disparities Begin: The Role Of Social And Economic Determinants--And Why Current Policies May Make Matters Worse|journal=Health Affairs|date=5 October 2011|volume=30|issue=10|pages=1852–1859|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2011.0685|pmid=21976326}}</ref> Minority neighborhoods have been continuously noted to have more fast food chains and fewer grocery stores than predominantly white neighborhoods.<ref name="Woolf 1852–1859"/> These food deserts affect a family’s ability to have easy access to nutritious food for their children. This lack of nutritious food extends beyond the household into the schools that have a variety of vending machines and deliver over processed foods.<ref name="Woolf 1852–1859"/> These environmental condition have social ramifications and in the first time in US history is it projected that the current generation will live shorter lives than their predecessors will.<ref name="Woolf 1852–1859"/>
In addition, minority neighborhoods have various health hazards that result from living close to highways and toxic waste factories or general dilapidated structures and streets.<ref name="Woolf 1852–1859"/> These environmental conditions create varying degrees of health risk from noise pollution, to carcinogenic toxic exposures from asbestos and radon that result in increase chronic disease, morbidity, and mortality.<ref name="Andersen 2007 45–50">{{cite book|last=Andersen|first=RM|title=Challenging the US Health Care System: Key Issues in Health Services Policy and Management|year=2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|pages=45–50}}</ref> The quality of residential environment such as damaged housing has been shown to increase the risk of adverse birth outcomes, which is reflective of a communities health.<ref name="Miranda">{{cite journal|last=Miranda|first=Marie Lynn|author2=Messer, Lynne C. |author3=Kroeger, Gretchen L. |title=Associations Between the Quality of the Residential Built Environment and Pregnancy Outcomes Among Women in North Carolina|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|date=2 December 2011|doi=10.1289/ehp.1103578|volume=120|issue=3|pages=471–477|pmid=22138639|pmc=3295337}}</ref> Housing conditions can create varying degrees of health risk that lead to complications of birth and long-term consequences in the aging population.<ref name="Miranda"/> In addition, occupational hazards can add to the detrimental effects of poor housing conditions. It has been reported that a greater number of minorities work in jobs that have higher rates of exposure to toxic chemical, dust and fumes.<ref name="Williams 1995 349–386">{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=David R.|author2=Chiquita Collins|title=US Socioeconomic and Racial Differences in Health|journal=Annual Review of Sociology|year=1995|volume=21|pages=349–386|doi=10.1146/annurev.soc.21.1.349|issue=1}}</ref>
Racial segregation is another environmental factor that occurs through the discriminatory action of those organizations and working individuals within the real estate industry, whether in the housing markets or rentals. Even though residential segregation is noted in all minority groups, blacks tend to be segregated regardless of income level when compared to Latinos and Asians.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=D. R.|author2=Jackson, P. B.|title=Social Sources Of Racial Disparities In Health|journal=Health Affairs|date=1 March 2005|volume=24|issue=2|pages=325–334|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.24.2.325|pmid=15757915}}</ref> Thus, segregation results in minorities clustering in poor neighborhoods that have limited employment, medical care, and educational resources, which is associated with high rates of criminal behavior.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.24.2.325 | pmid=15757915 | title=Social Sources Of Racial Disparities In Health | journal=Health Affairs | date=2005 | volume=24 | issue=2 | pages=325–334 | first=D. R. | last=Williams}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=DR|author2=Collins C.|title=Racial residential segregation: A fundamental cause of racial disparities in health|journal=Public Health Reports|year=2001|volume=116|pages=404–416|doi=10.1016/s0033-3549(04)50068-7|pmid=12042604|issue=5|pmc=1497358}}</ref> In addition, segregation affects the health of individual residents because the environment is not conducive to physical exercise due to unsafe neighborhoods that lack recreational facilities and have nonexistent park space.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Racial and ethnic discrimination adds an additional element to the environment that individuals have to interact with daily. Individuals that reported discrimination have been shown to have an increase risk of hypertension in addition to other physiological stress related affects.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mujahid MS|title=Neighborhood stressors and race/ethnic differences in hypertension prevalence|journal=American Journal of Hypertension|year=2011|volume=24|issue=2|pages=187–193|doi=10.1038/ajh.2010.200|pmid=20847728|display-authors=etal|pmc=3319083}}</ref> The high magnitude of environmental, structural, socioeconomic stressors leads to further compromise on the psychological and physical being, which leads to poor health and disease.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gee|first=GC|author2=Payne-Sturges D|title=Environmental health disparities: A framework integrating psychosocial and environmental concepts|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|year=2004|volume=112|pages=1645–1653|doi=10.1289/ehp.7074|issue=17|pmid=15579407|pmc=1253653}}</ref>
Individuals living in rural areas, especially poor rural areas, have access to fewer health care resources. Although 20 percent of the U.S. population lives in rural areas, only 9 percent of physicians practice in rural settings. Individuals in rural areas typically must travel longer distances for care, experience long waiting times at clinics, or are unable to obtain the necessary health care they need in a timely manner. Rural areas characterized by a largely Hispanic population average 5.3 physicians per 10,000 residents compared with 8.7 physicians per 10,000 residents in nonrural areas. Financial barriers to access, including lack of health insurance, are also common among the urban poor.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality |url=https://innovations.ahrq.gov/profiles/field-based-outreach-workers-facilitate-access-health-care-and-social-services-underserved |title=Field-Based Outreach Workers Facilitate Access to Health Care and Social Services for Underserved Individuals in Rural Areas |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2013-05-13}}</ref>
==Disparities in access to health care==
Reasons for disparities in access to health care are many, but can include the following:
* '''Lack of [[universal health care]] or [[health insurance]] coverage'''. Without health insurance, patients are more likely to postpone medical care, go without needed medical care, go without prescription medicines, and be denied access to care.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tikkanen|first1=Roosa Sofia|last2=Woolhandler|first2=Steffie|last3=Himmelstein|first3=David U.|last4=Kressin|first4=Nancy R.|last5=Hanchate|first5=Amresh|last6=Lin|first6=Meng-Yun|last7=McCormick|first7=Danny|last8=Lasser|first8=Karen E.|title=Hospital Payer and Racial/Ethnic Mix at Private Academic Medical Centers in Boston and New York City|journal=International Journal of Health Services|volume=47|issue=3|date=2 February 2017|pages=460–476|doi=10.1177/0020731416689549|pmid=28152644|pmc=6090544}}</ref> Minority groups in the United States lack insurance coverage at higher rates than whites.<ref>Kaiser Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured (KCMU), "The Uninsured and Their Access to Health Care" (December 2003).</ref> This problem does not exist in countries with fully funded public health systems, such as the examplar of the [[National Health Service|NHS]]. * '''Lack of a regular source of care'''. Without access to a regular source of care, patients have greater difficulty obtaining care, fewer doctor visits, and more difficulty obtaining prescription drugs. Compared to whites, minority groups in the United States are less likely to have a doctor they go to on a regular basis and are more likely to use [[emergency rooms]] and [[clinics]] as their regular source of care.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Fryer G. E. |author2=Dovey S. M. |author3=Green L. A. | year = 2000 | title = The Importance of Having a Usual Source of Health Care | url = | journal = American Family Physician | volume = 62 | issue = | page = 477 }}</ref> In the United Kingdom, which is much more racially harmonious, this issue arises for a different reason; since 2004, NHS [[General practitioners|GPs]] have not been responsible for care out of normal GP surgery opening hours, leading to significantly higher attendances in [[Emergency department|A+E]] * '''Lack of financial resources'''. Although the lack of financial resources is a barrier to health care access for many Americans, the impact on access appears to be greater for minority populations.<ref>Commonwealth Fund (CMWF), [http://www.commonwealthfund.org/News/News-Releases/1999/May/Analysis-Of-Minority-Health-Reveals-Persistent--Widespread-Disparities.aspx "Analysis of Minority Health Reveals Persistent, Widespread Disparities,"] press release (May 14, 1999).</ref> * '''[[Legal]] barriers'''. Access to medical care by low-income immigrant minorities can be hindered by legal barriers to public insurance programs. For example, in the United States federal law bars states from providing [[Medicaid]] coverage to [[immigrants]] who have been in the country fewer than five years.<ref name="Goldberg, J. 2004 page 10">Goldberg, J., Hayes, W., and Huntley, J. "Understanding Health Disparities." Health Policy Institute of Ohio (November 2004), page 10.</ref> Another example could be when a non-English speaking person attends a clinic where the receptionist does not speak the person's language. This is mostly seen in Hispanic people who do not speak English. * '''Structural barriers'''. These barriers include poor transportation, an inability to schedule appointments quickly or during convenient hours, and excessive time spent in the waiting room, all of which affect a person's ability and willingness to obtain needed care.<ref>Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), "National Healthcare Disparities Report," U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (July 2003).</ref> * '''The health care financing system'''. The [[Institute of Medicine]] in the United States says fragmentation of the U.S. health care delivery and financing system is a barrier to accessing care. Racial and ethnic minorities are more likely to be enrolled in health insurance plans which place limits on covered services and offer a limited number of health care providers.<ref name="Goldberg, J. 2004 page 10"/> * '''Scarcity of providers'''. In inner cities, rural areas, and communities with high concentrations of minority populations, access to medical care can be limited due to the scarcity of primary care practitioners, specialists, and diagnostic facilities.<ref name="K. Collins, D. Hughes 2002">[http://www.commonwealthfund.org/Publications/Fund-Reports/2002/Mar/Diverse-Communities--Common-Concerns--Assessing-Health-Care-Quality-for-Minority-Americans.aspx K. Collins, D. Hughes, M. Doty, B. Ives, J. Edwards, and K. Tenney, "Diverse Communities, Common Concerns: Assessing Health Care Quality for Minority Americans]," Commonwealth Fund (March 2002).</ref> In the UK, [[Monitor (NHS)|Monitor]] (a [[quango]]) has a legal obligation to ensure that sufficient provision exists in all parts of the nation. * '''Linguistic barriers'''. Language differences restrict access to medical care for minorities in the United States who are not [[English language|English]]-proficient.<ref>National Health Law Program and the Access Project (NHeLP), Language Services Action Kit: Interpreter Services in Health Care Settings for People With Limited English Proficiency (February 2004).</ref> * '''Health [[literacy]].''' This is where patients have problems obtaining, processing, and understanding basic health information. For example, patients with a poor understanding of good health may not know when it is necessary to seek care for certain symptoms. While problems with health literacy are not limited to minority groups, the problem can be more pronounced in these groups than in whites due to socioeconomic and educational factors.<ref name="K. Collins, D. Hughes 2002"/> A study conducted in Mdantsane, South Africa depicts the correlation of maternal education and the antenatal visits for pregnancy.
